name: Kashi Vishwanath Temple
description: Kashi Vishwanath Temple is one of the holiest shrines dedicated to Lord Shiva and is believed to grant liberation from the cycle of birth and death. Located on the banks of the River Ganga, it has been destroyed and rebuilt several times through history, standing today as a powerful symbol of enduring faith and devotion.
significance: One of the 12 Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva
Considered the holiest Shiva temple in India
peakCrowd: Maha Shivaratri and Mondays of Shravan month
Best to visit early morning on weekdays for shorter queues
biggestHighlight: Jyotirlinga darshan with direct connection to Moksha belief

nearestAccess.road: Easily accessible by road within the city

name: Somnath Temple
description: Somnath Temple is regarded as the first among the twelve Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva and holds immense historical and spiritual significance. The temple has been reconstructed multiple times after repeated invasions, representing resilience, continuity, and unwavering belief.
significance: First among the 12 Jyotirlingas of Lord Shiva
Rebuilt multiple times symbolizing resilience of faith
biggestHighlight: Seaside temple with evening aarti and sound & light show

nearestAccess.road: Road connectivity from major Gujarat cities

name: Kedarnath Temple
description: Situated high in the Himalayas, Kedarnath Temple is one of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites and a revered Jyotirlinga of Lord Shiva. Built with massive stone slabs, the temple has withstood extreme natural conditions and famously survived the 2013 floods, reinforcing its sacred stature.
significance: One of the Char Dham and 12 Jyotirlingas
Located at 11,755 ft in the Himalayas
peakCrowd: September is best for fewer crowds and clear weather
biggestHighlight: Ancient stone temple amidst snow-clad mountains

name: Badrinath Temple
description: Badrinath Temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and is an important part of the Char Dham yatra. Nestled along the Alaknanda River, the temple remains open only during summer months due to harsh winters, and the deity is worshipped in a rare meditative posture.
significance: One of the Char Dham dedicated to Lord Vishnu
biggestHighlight: Vishnu idol worshipped in meditative posture

name: Ramanathaswamy Temple
description: Ramanathaswamy Temple is renowned for its magnificent corridors, which are the longest among all Hindu temples. It is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas and a Char Dham site, where pilgrims perform ritual baths in sacred wells before seeking darshan.
significance: One of the Char Dham and Jyotirlingas
Famous for longest temple corridors in India
peakCrowd: Early mornings on weekdays are peaceful
biggestHighlight: 22 holy water theertham baths inside temple

name: Meenakshi Amman Temple
description: Meenakshi Amman Temple is the heart of Madurai and a masterpiece of Dravidian architecture. Dedicated to Goddess Meenakshi and Lord Sundareswarar, the temple is known for its towering gopurams covered with vibrant sculptures and its rich cultural heritage.
significance: Historic Dravidian temple dedicated to Goddess Meenakshi
biggestHighlight: Celestial wedding of Meenakshi and Sundareswarar

name: Jagannath Temple
description: Jagannath Temple is one of the four Char Dham pilgrimage sites and follows unique rituals distinct from other temples. The annual Rath Yatra, during which the deities are taken out in massive chariots, attracts millions of devotees from across the world.
significance: Lord Jagannath worshipped with unique rituals
biggestHighlight: Rath Yatra where deities come out to devotees

name: Dwarkadhish Temple
description: Dwarkadhish Temple is believed to stand at the site of Lord Krishna's ancient kingdom. The temple holds great significance for Vaishnavites, and archaeological findings of a submerged city near Dwarka add to its historical and spiritual importance.
biggestHighlight: Believed to be Krishna's ancient kingdom

name: Vaishno Devi Temple
description: Vaishno Devi Temple is one of the most visited Shakti shrines in India, located in the Trikuta Hills. The Goddess is worshipped in the form of natural rock manifestations, and the pilgrimage involves a challenging trek symbolizing devotion and perseverance.
significance: One of the most visited Shakti Peeths
biggestHighlight: Natural rock formations of the Goddess

name: Sabarimala Temple
description: Sabarimala Temple is dedicated to Lord Ayyappa and is known for its strict pilgrimage traditions. Devotees observe a forty-one-day period of penance before undertaking the journey, making it one of the largest and most disciplined pilgrimages in the world.

timings.weekdays: 3:00 AM onwards (Open only during specific seasons)
timings.weekends: 3:00 AM onwards (Open only during specific seasons)

biggestHighlight: 41-day vratham and sacred forest trek

name: Golden Temple
description: The Golden Temple is the holiest shrine of Sikhism and a symbol of equality and humility. It welcomes people of all religions and operates a community kitchen that serves free meals to thousands of visitors every day.
significance: Open to people of all faiths
biggestHighlight: Community kitchen (Langar) serving thousands daily

name: Akshardham Temple
description: Akshardham Temple is a grand cultural and spiritual complex showcasing traditional Indian architecture. Built entirely with stone and ancient construction techniques, it reflects the teachings of Bhagwan Swaminarayan and India's rich spiritual heritage.
biggestHighlight: Grand carvings and cultural exhibitions

name: Tiruvannamalai Arunachaleswarar Temple
description: Arunachaleswarar Temple represents the fire element among the Pancha Bhoota Sthalams dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple is closely associated with the sacred Arunachala Hill, where circumambulation is considered a powerful spiritual practice.
significance: One of Pancha Bhoota temples (Fire element)
biggestHighlight: Girivalam (14 km circumambulation of hill)

name: Kamakhya Temple
description: Kamakhya Temple is one of the most important Shakti Peethas in India and a major center of tantric worship. The temple is unique for celebrating the fertility cycle of the Goddess, especially during the annual Ambubachi Mela.
biggestHighlight: Unique fertility worship tradition

name: Lingaraja Temple
description: Lingaraja Temple is an ancient Shiva temple and a fine example of Kalinga-style architecture. Dedicated to Harihara, a combined form of Shiva and Vishnu, it stands as a central spiritual landmark of Bhubaneswar.
biggestHighlight: 1000-year-old living temple

name: Mahakaleshwar Temple
description: Mahakaleshwar Temple is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas and is unique for its south-facing Shiva lingam. The temple is especially famous for the early morning Bhasma Aarti, which draws devotees from across the country.
biggestHighlight: Unique south-facing Jyotirlinga

name: Brihadeeswarar Temple
description: Brihadeeswarar Temple, built by Raja Raja Chola, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a marvel of ancient engineering. Constructed entirely of granite, the temple's towering vimana reflects the architectural excellence of the Chola dynasty.
biggestHighlight: Massive Nandi and towering vimana

name: Chidambaram Nataraja Temple
description: Chidambaram Nataraja Temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva in his cosmic dancer form. It represents the element of space and is renowned for the Chidambara Rahasyam, symbolizing the concept of formless divinity.
significance: Dedicated to Lord Shiva as cosmic dancer
biggestHighlight: Chidambara Rahasyam (formless Shiva)

name: Kalighat Temple
description: Kalighat Temple is one of the fifty-one Shakti Peethas and is dedicated to Goddess Kali. It is believed that parts of Goddess Sati fell at this site, making it a powerful center of Shakti worship.
biggestHighlight: Ancient idol worshipped in unique form

name: ISKCON Temple
description: The ISKCON Temple in Vrindavan stands in the sacred land associated with Lord Krishna's childhood. It is known for its devotional atmosphere, continuous kirtans, and a strong global devotee community.
biggestHighlight: Bhajan, kirtan and spiritual atmosphere
